page.title: 01Local History
page.content: . Like many other villages, Drax and Barlow were at one time almost wholly agricultural in character. Drax - from the Old English word Draeg meaning a place where boats were lifted from the River Ouse and dragged overland to the River Aire - contains the site of a mediaeval abbey and a Norman castle. Barlow - from the Old English meaning the clearing where barley was grown - retains a 17th century chapel of ease, and the site of an Elizabethan manor house.There is also a huge derelict area which was formerly the site where airships were constructed and was later used as an army ordnance depot. With the progress of transport and communications and the establishment of new industries in the area, the villages are now much less insular.
